text.0: where is that hero who hath looked on indra borne on lightrolling car by tawny coursers.
text.1: who thunderer seeks with wealth the somapresser and to his house goes muchinvoked to aid him.
text.2: i have beheld his strong and secret dwelling longing have sought the founders habitation.
text.3: i asked of others and they said in answer may we awakened men attain to indra.
text.4: we will tell indra when we pour libation what mighty deeds thou hast performed to please us.
text.5: let him who knows not learn who knows them listen hither rides maghavan with all his army.
text.6: indra when born thou madest firm thy spirit alone thou seekest war to fight with many.
text.7: with might thou clavest een the rock asunder and foundest out the stable of the milchkine.
text.8: when thou wast born supremest at a distance bearing a name renowned in faroff regions.
text.9: since then een gods have been afraid of indra he conquered all the floods which served the dāsa.
text.10: these blissful maruts sing their psalm to praise thee and pour to thee libation of the soma.
text.11: indra with wondrous powers subdued the dragon the guileful lurker who beset the waters.
text.12: thou maghavan from the first didst scatter foemen speeding while joying in the milk the giver.
text.13: there seeking mans prosperity thou torest away the head of namuci the dāsa.
text.14: pounding the head of namuci the dāsa me too thou madest thine associate indra.
text.15: yea and the rolling stone that is in heaven both worlds as on a car brought to the maruts.
text.16: women for weapons hath the dāsa taken what injury can his feeble armies to me.
text.17: well he distinguished his two different voices and indra then advanced to fight the dasyu.
text.18: divided from their calves the cows went lowing around on every side hither and thither.
text.19: these indra reunited with his helpers what time the wellpressed soma made him joyful.
text.20: what time the somas mixed by babhru cheered him loud the steer bellowed in his habitations.
text.21: so indra drank thereof the fortdestroyer and gave him guerdon in return of milchkine.
text.22: this good deed have the rusamas done agni that they have granted me four thousand cattle.
text.23: we have received rnancayas wealth of heroes the most heroic which was freely offered.
text.24: the rusamas o agni sent me homeward with fair adornment and with kine in thousands.
text.25: the strong libations have made indra joyful when night whose course was ending changed to morning.
text.26: night wellnigh ended at rnancayas coming king of the rusamas was changed to morning.
text.27: like a strong courser fleet of foot urged onward babhru hath gained four thousand as his guerdon.
text.28: we have received four thousand head of cattle presented by the rusamas o agni.
text.29: and we the singers have received the caldron of metal which was heated for pravargya.
